description:
Actinoplanes derwentensis is a species of bacteria belonging to the genus Actinoplanes. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and spore-forming actinobacterium. The cells of A. derwentensis are typically rod-shaped and exhibit a characteristic mycelial growth pattern, forming a branched and substrate-penetrating vegetative mycelium.

This species was originally isolated from soil samples collected near the Derwent River in Tasmania, Australia, hence the specific epithet "derwentensis." A. derwentensis is known to produce a variety of secondary metabolites, including antibiotics and other bioactive compounds, which can be of potential interest in the field of pharmaceutical and biotechnological applications.

The genome of A. derwentensis has been sequenced, providing insights into its genetic potential and metabolic capabilities. Further research on this species may contribute to a better understanding of its ecological roles, biosynthetic pathways, and possible biotechnological applications.
